subject: Art
title: Brushwork & Brush Types
description: How brush shape, size, and technique change the character of a painting.

hook.text: A single brushstroke can be a leaf, a wrinkle, a wave, or a lock of hair â€” if the brush and technique are right. Brushwork is the painter's handwriting, and each brush type has its own vocabulary.

buildup.text: Brush types: flat (rectangular marks, sharp edges, good for blocking), round (pointed, versatile, good for detail), filbert (oval tip, soft blending), fan (splayed, for textures like grass/hair), palette knife (thick, sculptural paint application).

discovery.text: The biggest beginner mistake: using small brushes for everything. Start with the LARGEST brush that will fit the area. Big brushes force bold, confident marks and prevent fussy overworking. Switch to smaller brushes only for final details.

twist.text: Visible brushwork adds energy and life â€” trying to hide every brushstroke creates a lifeless, overworked surface. Impressionists proved that visible, confident brushwork can be more alive than smooth perfection.

climax.text: Paint the same simple still life three times: once with only a flat brush, once with only a round brush, once with a palette knife. Each tool creates a completely different painting character â€” from the same subject.

punchline.text: The brush is a voice. Each one sings differently. Learn their songs and your painting vocabulary expands.

quiz.question: Why should painters start with the largest appropriate brush?
options: Large brushes force bold, confident marks and prevent overworking with fussy small details
It doesn't matter which size you start with
